title: Show HN: Airdraw
description:
Hey Everyone! I wanted to show my passion project I made a few years back and recently turned into a web app.

Airdraw is an app that takes in your hand gestures and converts it into real time drawing capabilities.

There are tons of stuff I want to build with this, but most importantly just put it out into the world! Hope you all enjoy :)

I included a link to the original GH project I wrote here - https://github.com/arefmalek/airdraw and a link to the blog where I explained how I made it here - https://arefmalek.github.io/blog/Airdraw/

Show HN: Octopus – a directed acyclic graph for app development
description:
Directed acyclic graphs are muched discussed in comp-sci, but octopus appears to be the first reusable, turnkey, ready-to-wear, off-the-shelf implementation of a DAG for application development, in any language, that I'm aware of.

This is remarkable because DAGs hit a sweet spot in the middle of the three common programming paradigms (OO, event-driven, functional). Let's have a DAG as the top-level structure of our applications. Data-fetching and onChange handlers live in DAG nodes, next to the data they act on. The UI flows out from the DAG with fine-grained reactivity. Our app state is effortlessly consistent, because any outside change (user action, api result) unleashes a graph traversal. Our UI components become much simpler, because they just need to dumbly reflect values in the graph.

I'm putting this up for a second time. Absolutely no-one bit the first time, which can't be right :-)

Comments URL: ht

Ask HN: Daily practices for building AI/ML skills?
description:
Say I have around 1 hour daily allocated to developing AI/ML skills.

What in your opinion is the best way to invest the time/energy?

1. Build small projects (build what?)

2. Read blogs/newsletters (which ones?)

3. Take courses (which courses?)

4. Read textbooks (which books?)

6. Kaggle competitions

7. Participate in AI/ML forums/communities

8. A combination of the above (if possible share time % allocation/weightage)

Asking this in general to help good SE people build up capabilities in ML.

Comments URL: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=38638373
